author: Sarah Sloat
title: Volkswagen will put nonessential projects, investments under review
text:
FRANKFURT-- Volkswagen AG will put all nonessential projects and investments under review as it contends with the diesel emissions scandal, the company’s new chief executive officer and its top labor official told staff Tuesday.
“We have to question everything that no longer makes economic sense,” Bernd Osterloh said at a briefing on the situation in Wolfsburg.
For now, jobs aren’t at stake, Osterloh told about 20,000 workers who gathered for the briefing.
“At the moment that’s the good news--that there are as yet no consequences for jobs,” he said, but warned that the company still has to assess how customers react to the scandal.
While executive bonuses will have to be reviewed, Osterloh said Volkswagen VOW, +1.49% VLKAY, +1.76% employees shouldn’t have “to pick up the tab for the misconduct a group of managers.”
Volkswagen employs about 600,000 people world-wide.
Europe’s largest auto maker faces an enormous recall after it was revealed last month that it had installed software that allows cars to run cleaner during emissions testing. The software is installed in about 11 million vehicles, but may not be activated in all of them.
